'''California pottery''' includes industrial, commercial, and decorative [[pottery]] produced in the [[Northern California]] and [[Southern California]] regions of the U.S. state of [[California]]. Production includes [[brick]], [[Sanitary sewer|sewer pipe]], [[Architectural terracotta|architectural terra cotta]], [[tile]], garden ware, [[tableware]], [[kitchenware]], [[art ware]], [[figurine]]s, [[giftware]], and [[industrial ceramic|ceramics for industrial use]]. [[Ceramic]]s include [[terra cotta]], [[earthenware]], [[porcelain]], and [[stoneware]] products.
[[File:Freeman leidy bird.jpg|thumb|''Ceramic Originals'' by Freeman-Leidy, [[Crane (bird)|crane]] [[figurine]].]] Key milestones in the history of California pottery include: the arrival of Spanish settlers, the advent of Statehood and subsequent population growth, the [[arts and crafts movement]], [[Great Depression]], [[World War II]] era and the post-WWII onslaught of low-priced imports leading to a steep decline in the number of California potteries. California potters large and small have left a legacy of tableware design, collectibles, art, and architecture.
== History == Tile has been a favorite building material in California since the early Spanish settled the area and brought with them the tradition of using brightly-colored tiles in architecture. Helen Stiles, author of numerous books on the history of pottery, noted that [[Spain|Spanish]], [[Mexico|Mexican]], and [[China|Chinese]] design of the 17th and 18th centuries all influenced the decoration of tile and other pottery in California.<ref name=stiles>{{cite book|last=Stiles|first=Helen E.|title=Pottery in the United States|year=1941|publisher=E.P. Dutton & Co., Inc.|location=New York|pages= 140}}</ref>
As people moved into California after statehood in 1848, the demand for ceramic products grew exponentially. Buildings needed roofs, floors, and sewer pipes. The ceramic industry grew as the demand increased. The "Golden Era in tile making"<ref name= catile02 /> and [[art pottery]], influenced by the [[Arts and Crafts movement]], was around 1910. Architect [[Julia Morgan]] used tiles to adorn her buildings including the [[Hearst Castle]] in the 1920s.
The most active period for the production of household ceramics including tableware, kitchenware, giftware, and [[art ware]] was from the 1930s through the 1960s.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} The major area of U.S. household ceramics production was in the [[Los Angeles basin]].{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} Around Los Angeles there were over 300 producers of figurines. Next in size was the [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]] area, followed by [[East Liverpool, Ohio|East Liverpool]], and a few in the middle west such as [[Ceramic Arts Studio]], [[Red Wing Pottery]] and [[Haeger Potteries]].<ref name=ci1044>{{cite journal|title=A Brave New Label Figurines, Made in U.S.A.|journal=Ceramic Industry|date=October 1944}}</ref>
The period around [[World War II]] saw the greatest growth for the U.S. ceramic industry.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} With imports cut off from European and Asian markets, small family-owned and larger potteries stepped in to fill the need for ceramic giftware and tableware throughout the United States. By 1948, "the peak year for the industry, over eight hundred ceramic concerns were in operation throughout California." <ref name=chipmanCP /> With sunlight year round, an abundance of raw materials, and relatively inexpensive natural gas, California became competitive with centers of ceramic production such as the "Pottery Capital of the World" [[East Liverpool, Ohio]] and [[Stoke-on-Trent]], [[Staffordshire]], [[England]].
In the 1950s, favorable trade agreements toward Asian countries contributed to a flood of competitively priced ceramic wares entering the [[United States]] market. Only a fraction of California potteries survived this competition through the early 1960s. Today, only a few are still in business.
=== "Big Five" California potteries === The "Big Five"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Colored Pottery, California Manufacturers Lead the World in Beauty of Design and Coloring|journal=California Magazine of Pacific Business|date=September 1937|pages=16}}</ref> California potteries, from the 1930s to the 1960s in reference to the range of products and output, were [[Vernon Kilns]], [[Bauer Pottery|J.A. Bauer Pottery]], [[Metlox Pottery|Metlox Potteries]], [[Pacific Pottery|Pacific Clay Products]], and [[Gladding, McBean|Gladding, McBean & Co]]. All of the "Big Five" potteries operated production facilities in the [[Los Angeles Basin]]. Gladding, McBean & Co. grew from one factory manufacturing sewer pipe and architectural terra cotta in Lincoln, California to factories throughout California and the [[Pacific Northwest]]. Vernon Kilns closed in 1958, J.A. Bauer in 1962, and Metlox in 1988. The former Gladding, McBean & Co.'s Franciscan tableware and tile factory in Los Angeles was bought by [[Wedgwood]] from the Interpace corporation in 1979. Wedgwood closed the Franciscan Ceramics plant in 1984, moving production of the Franciscan tableware brands to England. The former Gladding, McBean & Co.'s Lincoln factory was purchased by Pacific Coast Building Products in 1976 and continues to produce sewer pipe, architectural terra cotta, and terra cotta garden ware. Pacific Clay Products discontinued manufacturing tableware, art ware, and figurines in 1942. Pacific Clay Products continues to manufacture sewer pipe.

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Department of Energy |type = Department |nativename = ''Kagawaran ng Enerhiya'' |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = Seal of the Department of Energy (Philippines).svg |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = December 9, 1992 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = Energy Center, Rizal Drive, [[Fort Bonifacio]], [[Taguig City]] |coordinates = |employees = |budget = {{Philippine peso|3.5 Billion}} (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=GAA 2015|url=http://www.dbm.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/GAA/GAA2015/GAA%202015%20Volume%20II%20A-B/SUMMARY.pdf|work=DBM|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref> |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo =
|chief1_name = [[Alfonso Cusi]] |chief1_position = Secretary |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|www.doe.gov.ph}} |footnotes = }} The [[Philippines|Philippines']] '''Department of Energy''' ({{lang-fil|Kagawaran ng Enerhiya|}}, abbreviated as '''DOE''') is the [[Executive Departments of the Philippines|executive department]] of the [[Philippine Government]] responsible for preparing, integrating, manipulating, organizing, coordinating, supervising and controlling all plans, programs, projects and activities of the Government relative to energy exploration, development, utilization, distribution and conservation.
==History== The Department of Energy was created by then President Marcos as he issued Presidential Decree No. 1206 which created the Ministry of Energy and attached the National Power Corporation and Philippine National Oil Company to this new agency. The Ministry and its two bureaus (Bureau of Energy Development and Bureau of Energy Utilization) remained intact but was downgraded into a mere Office of Energy Affairs--headed by Wenceslao de la Paz and reporting to then Deputy Executive Secretary for Energy Catalino Macaraig, Jr. based in Malacanang--during the regime of President Corazon Aquino. During the regime of President Fidel V. Ramos, the Department was created due to [http://www.doe.gov.ph/popup/RA%207638.pdf Republic Act No. 7638] otherwise known as the ''Department of Energy Act of 1992''.
The Department was vested additional powers and functions under pertinent energy and power-related legislations, such as Republic Act (RA) No. 9136 or the "Electric Power Industry Reform Act of 2001", RA No. 9367 or "Biofuels Act of 2006", and RA No. 9513 or "Renewable Energy Act of 2008.
==Organization== The Department is headed by the Secretary of Energy who is assisted by three Undersecretaries and three Assistant Secretaries. Under the Department are the Administrative Service, Financial Service, Information Technology and Management Service, Legal Service and Energy Research Testing and Laboratory Service.
The Department is composed of the following bureaus: *Energy Resource Development Bureau, *Energy Utilization Management Bureau, *Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, *Oil Industry Management Bureau, *Electric Power Industry Management Bureau, and *Renewable Energy Management Bureau.
The following units, agencies and corporations are attached to the Department: *National Biofuels Board (NBB) *[[National Power Corporation]] (NPC/Napocor) *[[National Transmission Corporation]] (TransCo) *[[National Electrification Administration]] (NEA) *[[Philippine National Oil Company]] (PNOC) *Power Sector Assets and Liabilities Management Corporation (PSALM Corp.)
== List of the Secretaries of the Department of Energy == {{main|Secretary of Energy (Philippines)}}
==Major Projects== ===Philippine Energy Plan 2009â2030===
Due to the rapid growth of the country's population<ref>http://www.indexmundi.com/g/r.aspx?c=rp&v=24</ref> and the interrelated growing of the country's demand for energy,<ref>http://www.doe.gov.ph/efficiency/energy_outlook.htm</ref> the Department of Energy (DOE) introduced its [[Philippine]] Energy Plan 2009â2030.<ref>http://www.doe.gov.ph/PEP/default.htm</ref>
The plan for the period 2009â2030 mentions three broad policy thrusts based on the concept of enabling better energy choices for a better quality of life.
On April 28, 2010, Director Jesus Tamang<ref>http://www.philippinechamber.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=846:doe-presents-philippine-energy-plan&catid=31:energy&Itemid=78</ref> of the Energy Policy and Planning Bureau explained that keeping the self-sufficiency level on nearly 60% will be challenging, but he also stated that a way to counter-streer this massive population growth was the country's future investments in new projects that are targeted in the plan.
The DOE's proposal consists of these following three principles that will have an important impact within the next 20 years on the countryâs energy future:
====Ensure energy security==== * Accelerate the exploration and development of oil, gas and coal resources * Intensify development and utilization of renewable and environment-friendly alternative energy resources and technologies * Enhance energy efficiency and conservation * Put in place long-term reliable power supply * Improve transmission and distribution systems * Secure vital energy infrastructure and facilities * Maintain a competitive energy investment climate
====Pursue effective implementation of energy sector reforms==== * Monitor the implementation of, and if necessary, recommend amendments to, existing energy laws * Promote an efficient, competitive, transparent and reliable energy sector * Advocate the passage of new and necessary laws
====Implement social mobilization and cross-sector monitoring mechanisms==== * Expand reach through information, education and communication * Establish cross-sector monitoring mechanism in cooperation with other national government agencies, academe, local government units, non-government organizations and other local and international organizations * Promote good governance
==See also== *[[U.S. Department of Energy]] *[[Department of Energy (United Kingdom)]]

A '''dielectric resonator antenna''' (DRA) is a radio [[antenna (radio)|antenna]] mostly used at [[microwave]] frequencies and higher, that consists of a block of [[ceramic]] material of various shapes, the [[dielectric resonator]], mounted on a metal surface, a [[ground plane]]. Radio waves are introduced into the inside of the resonator material from the [[transmitter]] circuit and bounce back and forth between the resonator walls, forming [[standing waves]]. The walls of the resonator are partially transparent to radio waves, allowing the radio power to radiate into space.<ref name="Huang">{{cite book | last = Huang | first = Kao-Cheng | authorlink = |author2=David J. Edwards | title = Millimetre wave antennas for gigabit wireless communications: a practical guide to design and analysis in a system context | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | year = 2008 | location = USA | pages = 115â121 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G4CggacS5qUC&pg=PA115&dq=%22dielectric+resonator+antenna%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FeRAT6e-IMXhiAL-sMUm&ved=0CEwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22dielectric%20resonator%20antenna%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-470-51598-8}}</ref>
An advantage of dielectric resonator antennas is they lack metal parts, which become lossy at high frequencies, dissipating energy. So these antennas can have lower losses and be more efficient than metal antennas at high microwave and [[millimeter wave]] frequencies.<ref name="Huang" /> Dielectric waveguide antennas are used in some compact portable wireless devices, and military millimeter-wave radar equipment. The antenna was first proposed by Robert Richtmyer in 1939.<ref>{{Citation|first1=Robert|last1=Richtmeyer|title=Dielectric Resonators,|journal=Journal of Applied Physics|volume=10|pages=391|year=1939|doi=10.1063/1.1707320}}</ref> In 1982, Long et al. did the first design and test of dielectric resonator antennas considering a leaky waveguide model assuming magnetic conductor model of the dielectric surface .<ref>{{Citation|first1=S.|last1=Long|first2=M.|last2=McAllister|first3=L.|last3=Shen|title=The Resonant Cylindrical Dielectric Resonator Antenna,|journal=IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation|volume=31|pages=406â412|year=1983|doi=10.1109/tap.1983.1143080}}</ref>
An antenna like effect is achieved by periodic swing of electrons from its capacitive element to the ground plane which behaves like an inductor. The authors further argued that the operation of a dielectric antenna resembles the antenna conceived by [[Guglielmo_Marconi|Marconi]], the only difference is that inductive element is replaced by the dielectric material.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Theory Leads to Gigahertz Antenna on Chip|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/telecom/wireless/gigahertz-antenna-on-a-chip |accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref>
==Features== Dielectric resonator antennas offer the following attractive features:
* The dimension of a DRA is of the order of <math>\frac{\lambda_0} {\sqrt{\epsilon_r}}</math>, where <math>\lambda_0</math> is the free-space wavelength and <math>\epsilon_r</math> is the [[Relative static permittivity|dielectric constant]] of the resonator material. Thus, by choosing a high value of <math>\epsilon_r</math> (<math>\epsilon_r\approx10-100</math>), the size of the DRA can be significantly reduced. * There is no inherent conductor loss in dielectric resonators. This leads to high radiation efficiency of the antenna. This feature is especially attractive for millimeter (mm)-wave antennas, where the loss in metal fabricated antennas can be high. * DRAs offer simple coupling schemes to nearly all transmission lines used at microwave and mm-wave frequencies. This makes them suitable for integration into different planar technologies. The coupling between a DRA and the planar transmission line can be easily controlled by varying the position of the DRA with respect to the line. The performance of DRA can therefore be easily optimized experimentally. * The operating bandwidth of a DRA can be varied over a wide range by suitably choosing resonator parameters. For example, the bandwidth of the lower order modes of a DRA can be easily varied from a fraction of a percent to about 20% or more by the suitable choice of the dielectric constant of the material and/or by strategic shaping of the DRA element. *Use of multiple modes radiating identically has also been successfully addressed. * Each mode of a DRA has a unique internal and associated external field distribution. Therefore, different radiation characteristics can be obtained by exciting different modes of a DRA.

{{notability|Companies|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox company| | name = Digital Storm | type = Private | foundation = 2002 | location = 47811 Warm Springs Blvd
[[Fremont, California|Fremont]], [[California]] | industry = [[Computer hardware]] |area_served = Worldwide | products = [[Desktop computer|Desktops]]
[[Laptop|Notebook]]s
[[Peripheral]]s | num_employees = 37[http://www.bbb.org/greater-san-francisco/business-reviews/computers-wholesale-and-manufacturers/digital-storm-in-fremont-ca-301630 Better Business Bureau (retrieved on 4/23/13)] | homepage = [http://www.digitalstorm.com/ digitalstorm.com] }} '''Digital Storm''' is a privately owned [[boutique computer]] manufacturer in the United States that primarily specializes on high-performance [[gaming computer|gaming desktop]] and [[laptop]] computers. Headquartered in [[Fremont, California|Fremont]], [[California]],{{cite web | url=http://www.digitalstormonline.com/companyinfo.asp | title=Digital Storm Company Profile | accessdate=2013-05-01}} the company also sells upgrade components and gaming peripherals, such as headsets, gaming mice, custom keyboards and high-resolution computer monitors. == History == Digital Storm was founded in 2002. Originally an internet retailer of computer components, the company began building custom gaming PCs after repeated requests by customers for pre-assembled systems. The first custom-built PC system the company ever marketed was the Digital Storm Twister.{{cite web | url=http://www.pcper.com/reviews/Systems/Digital-Storm-Twister-Extreme-3-Way-SLI-System-Review| title=Digital Storm Twister Extreme 3-Way SLI System Review | publisher=PC Perspective | date=December 21, 2007 | accessdate=2013-14-24 | last=Shrout | first=Ryan}} In 2012, the company began designing proprietary designs, starting with their Aventum and the Bolt models. == Products == Focusing heavily on the gaming market, Digital Stormâs designs for gaming desktops and laptops focus primarily on high-performance custom PC configurations, though they also produce [[workstation]] models.{{cite web |url=http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm%e2%80%99s-davinci-ushers-in-workstation-renaissance-for-creative-professionals/ |title=Digital Stormâs DAVINCI Ushers in Workstation Renaissance for Creative Professionals |publisher=Max Borges Agency |date=March 17, 2010 |accessdate=2013-14-24 |last=Metcalf |first=Brian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129025855/http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm%E2%80%99s-davinci-ushers-in-workstation-renaissance-for-creative-professionals/ |archivedate=2011-11-29 |df= }} They specialize in customizing each machine with features such as [[overclocking]], dual video card implementations (such as [[Scalable Link Interface|SLI]]), [[RAID]] arrays, [[computer cooling|liquid-cooling]] systems and [[quiet PC|noise-reduction]] modifications. Digital Storm also sells upgrade PC components such as computer memory, video cards, CPUs, motherboards, hard drives, cooling systems and computer monitors. They also offer accessories aimed at gamers, such as custom keyboards, audio headsets and gaming mice. == Notable services == === Custom case designs === In 2013, they began offering a service called LaserMark, which allows custom images to be etched onto computer cases.{{cite web|url=http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-debuts-lasermark-service/ |title=Digital Storm Debuts LaserMark Service |publisher=Max Borges Agency |date=October 20, 2011 |accessdate=2013-14-24 |last=Metcalf |first=Brian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121126214938/http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-debuts-lasermark-service/ |archivedate=2012-11-26 |df= }} === Overclocking === The company offers custom overclocking of CPUs and GPUs through its âTwister Boostâ technology on many of its gaming computers. === Stress-testing === Before shipping out an order, a technician for Digital Storm performs 72-hour [[stress-testing|stress testing]] and quality control to screen for assembly errors, faulty components and other quality issues. === Liquid-cooling === On most desktop models, Digital Storm offers Cryo-TEC{{cite web|url=http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-empowers-supreme-processor-performance-with-cryo-tec-cooling-system-in-gaming-computers/ |title=Digital Storm Empowers Supreme Processor Performance with Cryo-TEC Cooling System in Gaming Computers |publisher=Max Borges Agency |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=2013-14-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211174455/http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-empowers-supreme-processor-performance-with-cryo-tec-cooling-system-in-gaming-computers/ |archivedate=2011-12-11 |df= }} and Sub-Zero{{cite web|url=http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-debuts-sub-zero-liquid-chilled-system/ |title=Digital Storm Debuts Sub-Zero Liquid Chilled System |publisher=Max Borges Agency |date=November 2, 2010 |accessdate=2013-14-24 |last=Metcalf |first=Brian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130329125841/http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-debuts-sub-zero-liquid-chilled-system/ |archivedate=2013-03-29 |df= }} liquid cooling systems. == Accolades == Digital Stormâs systems are often reviewed by technology writers and gaming industry publications. For their more notable systems, they have received critical acclaim and awards. In 2012, the company was recognized as a Design and Engineering Award Honoree for its Cryo-TEC cooling system.{{cite web|url=http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-named-as-ces-innovations-2012-design-and-engineering-award-honoree/ |title=Digital Storm Named as CES Innovations 2012 Design and Engineering Award Honoree |publisher=Max Borges Agency |date=November 8, 2011 |accessdate=2013-14-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121126214844/http://maxborgesagency.com/press/digital-storm-named-as-ces-innovations-2012-design-and-engineering-award-honoree/ |archivedate=2012-11-26 |df= }} The Bolt, Digital Stormâs most successful gaming PC model, received [[Maximum PC]]âs "Kick-Ass Award" in 2013,{{cite web | url=http://www.maximumpc.com/article/%5bprimary-term%5d/digital_storm_bolt_review2013 | title=Digital Storm Bolt Review | publisher=Maximum PC | accessdate=2013-14-24 }} and also received special attention for the compact design and performance measurements. Ubergizmo called it the "thinnest gaming PC in the world."{{cite web | url=http://www.ubergizmo.com/2013/02/digital-storm-bolt-is-thinnest-gaming-pc-in-the-world/| title=Digital Storm Bolt is Thinnest Gaming PC In The World | publisher=Max Borges Agency | date=February 19, 2013 | accessdate=2013-14-24 }} The Aventum, another of the companyâs more popular models, won the "2012 Best of Whatâs New" award from the editors of Popular Science Magazine, who called it a "melt-down proof computer."{{cite web | url=http://www.popsci.com/bown/2012/innovator/digital-storm-aventum| title=Popsci Teardown: A Meltdown-Proof Computer | publisher=Popular Science Magazine | date=February 19, 2013 | accessdate=2013-14-24 |last=Safford | first=Matt }} == See also == *[[List of computer system manufacturers]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.digitalstormonline.com/}} *[http://www.digitalstormonline.com/unlocked// DS Unlocked] *[http://www.digitalstormonline.com/forums/forum_topics.asp?FID=33/ Tech support hub] *[http://www.digitalstormonline.com/forums// Gaming Community Forum] *[https://www.youtube.com/digitalstormpc#p/u/ DS Labs] *[http://www.digitalstormonline.com/forums/forum_topics.asp?FID=38/ Press reviews] [[Category:Computer hardware companies]] [[Category:Computer companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Miami-Dade County, Florida]] [[Category:Computer companies]]

{{Infobox company | name = eInfochips | type = [[Private company|Private]]<ref name="Bloomberg1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/companies/3470202Z:IN-einfochips-ltd|title=Company listing|publisher=Bloomberg Business|date=2016|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> | key_people = Pratul Shroff (CEO)<ref name="CIOStory1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ciostory.com/magazines/2015/iot-most-powerful-vendors/einfochips-providing-custom-solutions-with-better-scalability-and-roi|title=eInfochips : Providing Custom Solutions with Better Scalability and ROI|publisher=CIO Story|date=2016-02-13|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> | industry = [[Semiconductor industry|Semiconductors]], [[Aerospace engineering|Aerospace & Defense]], [[Consumer electronics|Consumer Electronics]], [[Medical device|Medical Devices]], [[Quality assurance|QA Practice]], [[Automation|Industrial Automation]], [[Retail|Retail & e-Commerce]], [[Independent software vendor|Software/ISV]], [[Mass surveillance industry|Security & Surveillance]], [[Healthcare industry|Healthcare]],<ref name="TexasInstruments1"/> | num_employees = 1800<ref name="Engerati1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.engerati.com/companies/einfochips/13931|title=Company description|publisher=Engerati|date=2016-02-13|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> | foundation = 1994 <ref name="SiliconIndia1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.siliconindia.com/magazine-articles-in/eInfochips_Chiseling_Employees__Skills_with_a_Healthy_Balance_...-KXBD358797070.html|title=eInfochips: Chiseling Employees - Skills with a Healthy Balance of Technical & Soft Skill Development Programs|publisher=Silicon India|date=2016-06-26|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> | location = [[SanJose, California]], United States and [[Ahmedabad, Gujarat]], India<ref name="TexasInstruments1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ti.com/devnet/docs/catalog/companyfolder.tsp?actionPerformed=companyFolder&companyId=298|title=TI Design Network Platinum Member |publisher=Texas Instruments|date=2016|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> | homepage = {{URL|www.einfochips.com}}<ref name="Engerati1"/> }}
'''eInfochips''' is a [[Product engineering|Product Engineering]] and [[Software engineering|Software R&D Services]] firm based in [[Sunnyvale, California]] that offers solutions in [[Software engineering|software]], [[Computer engineering|hardware]], [[Very-large-scale integration|VLSI]] and mechanical engineering services.<ref name="Engerati1"/> In January 2018, the company was acquired by Arrow Electronics (a Fortune #113 brand), for its specialization in IoT, product transformation and digital transformation capabilities. The company has developed its niche as a technology partner for several [[Fortune 500]] product companies and hi-tech firms such as [[Qualcomm]],<ref name="Qualcomm1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.qualcomm.com/news/snapdragon/2015/06/05/new-snapdragon-based-som-and-dev-kit-ioe-applications-einfochips|title=New Snapdragon based SoM and dev kit for IoE applications from eInfochips|publisher=Qualcommm|date=2015-06-15|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> [[Texas Instruments]],<ref name="TexasInstruments1"/><ref name="Embedded1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.embedded.com/electronics-products/electronic-product-reviews/debug-and-optimization/4434503/eInfochips-shrinks-design-cycles-by-6-months-for-TI-s-66AK2Ex-processors-|title=eInfochips shrinks design cycles by six months for TI's 66AK2Ex processors|publisher=Embedded Magazine|date=2014-09-10|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> [[Toshiba]],<ref name="DeccanHerald1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/483946/chip-designer-einfochips-upgrades-its.html|title=Chip designer eInfochips upgrades its guidance|publisher=Deccan Herald|date=2015-06-15|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref><ref name="EconomicTimes1">{{Cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-02-04/news/58795902_1_project-ara-einfochips-modules|title=Toshiba, Einfochips to develop chips for Google's Ara modules|publisher=Economic Times|date=2015-02-04|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> and [[Microsemi]]<ref name="Microsemi">{{Cite web|url=http://www.microsemi.com/products/fpga-soc/design-resources/partners/einfochips-aero|title=Microsemi Militaery and Aerospace Paretners|publisher=Microsemi|date=2016|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> and is also a development partner for companies including Microsoft, Amazon, and Intel. The company provides a range of products and services spanning multiple industries including [[Semiconductor industry|semiconductors]],<ref name="TexasInstruments1"/><ref name="Qualcomm1"/> [[Aerospace engineering|aerospace & defense]],<ref name="Microsemi"/> [[medical devices]],<ref name="Engerati1"/> [[Automation|industrial automation]],<ref name="Engerati1"/> [[Retail|retail & e-Commerce]],<ref name="Engerati1"/> [[Automotive industry|automotive]],<ref name="Qualcomm1"/> [[Mass surveillance industry|video surveillance]],<ref name="Engerati1"/> and smart city.<ref name="Qualcomm1"/>
The company further claims to have expertise in various technologies for [[Internet of Things]], [[Business intelligence|Business Intelligence]], [[Cloud computing|Cloud]], [[Deep learning|Deep Learning]] and [[Video content analysis|Video Analytics]].<ref name="DeccanHerald1"/> It has collaborated with its partners on a number of projects including [[LinkNYC]], an ambitious network to cover [[New York City]] with free [[Wi-Fi]] service by converting old [[payphone]]s into [[Hotspot (Wi-Fi)|hotspot]] points<ref name="Gizmodo1">{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/inside-the-tech-behind-new-yorks-monstrously-fast-gigab-1757905695|title=Inside the Tech Behind New York's Monstrously Fast Gigabit Wifi|publisher=Gizmodo|date=2016-02-11|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> and the global IoT network called [[ZigBee]] Alliance.<ref name="Zigbee1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.zigbee.org/member-release-einfochips-and-kroger-unveil-zigbee-based-retail-site-intelligence-for-stores-of-the-21st-century/|title=MEMBER RELEASE: eInfochips and Kroger Unveil ZigBee-based âRetail Site Intelligenceâ for Stores of the 21st Century|publisher=ZigBee|date=2014-04-02|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> It has further collaborated with [[Kroger]] on retail site intelligence solutions.<ref name="SecurityInfoWatch1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.securityinfowatch.com/article/11366107/kroger-einfochips-showcase-retail-site-intelligence-platform-at-isc-west|title=Kroger, eInfochips showcase 'Retail Site Intelligence' solution at ISC West|publisher=Security Site Intelligence|date=2014-04-12|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> einfochips was chosen by [[Rockwell Collins]] as their Global Supplier of the Year 2014 for Engineering and Design Services.<ref name="Microsemi"/><ref name="RockwellCollins1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockwellcollins.com/Data/News/2014_Cal_Year/RC/FY14RCNR24-SotY.aspx|title=Rockwell Collins names M/A-COM Technology Solutions as top supplier for 2014|date=2014-03-05|publisher=Rockwell Collins|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> It was able to shrink design cycles by six months for Texas Instrument's 6AK2Ex processors.<ref name="Embedded1"/>
==History==
eInfochips was founded in 1994 by Pratul Shroff.<ref name="SiliconIndia1"/> with global headquarters in both [[Ahmedabad]], India and [[Sunnyvale, California|Sunnyvale]], [[California]] and has 1500 employees worldwide.<ref name="SiliconIndia1"/> From its origins as a chip design company, it has over the years, diversified into complete product engineering and R&D services spanning multiple industries.<ref name="EFYTimes1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.efytimes.com/e1/78217/We-Were-Ranked-Number--Worldwide-In-Chip-Design |title=We Were Ranked Number 1 Worldwide In Chip Design |publisher=EFYTimes |date=2012-02-05 |accessdate=2016-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160217064421/http://www.efytimes.com/e1/78217/We-Were-Ranked-Number--Worldwide-In-Chip-Design |archivedate=2016-02-17 |df= }}</ref> It has further developed sales presence across [[Austin]], [[Boston]], [[Cedar Rapids]], [[Cincinnati]], [[Chicago]], [[Dallas]] and [[Raleigh]] in the US, [[Toronto]] (Canada), [[Tokyo]] (Japan) and [[London]] (UK).<ref name="Engerati1"/>
==Products and solutions==
eInfochips is primarily known in the semiconductor industry for its '''Eragon''' product line, which is a development platform based on [[Qualcomm Snapdragon]] processors.<ref name="Qualcomm1"/> It has found application across a variety of industry segments including industrial, security and surveillance, infotainment, [[avionics]] (in-flight entertainment), display systems (digital signage, smart vending), and Internet of Everything (IoE) systems, and also [[smart cities]], smart grid, smart transit and smart factories.<ref name="Qualcomm2">{{Cite web|url=https://developer.qualcomm.com/blog/additional-processing-power-new-embedded-development-platforms-einfochips|title=Additional Processing Power With New Embedded Development Platforms From eInfochips|publisher=Qualcomm|date=2015-06-04|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref> The Eragon600 System on Module (SoM) and the development kit was displayed at Embedded World 2015 conference in [[Nuremberg]], Germany, where the company showcased an interactive digital signage solution based on Snapdragon 600 processor. With real-time [[video analytics]] captured from an IP camera, eInfochips measured the attention span and popularity of the signage content, and updated it in real-time. The setup also included an AllJoynâ¢ based mobile application to empower viewers to interact with the digital signage content.<ref name="Qualcomm2"/>
According to Aviation Today magazine, eInfochips was one of the partners chosen by [[Microsemi]] to provide [[DO-254]] compliant design services for avionics systems.<ref name="AviationToday1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aviationtoday.com/av/topstories/Microsemi-eInfochips-Form-DO-254-Services-Partnership_82825.html#.Vr8zVPl97IU|title=Microsemi, eInfochips Form DO-254 Services Partnership|publisher=Aviation Today|date=2014-08-12|accessdate=2016-02-13}}</ref>

[[File:Thumkuhlenthal.jpg|thumb|Water wheel and flatrods (AufgeklÃ¤rtes GlÃ¼ck Mine)]] The '''flatrod system''' ({{lang-de|italic=yes|KunstgestÃ¤nge, Stangenkunst, Stangenwerk,}} or ''Stangenleitung''; {{lang-sv|italic=yes|KonstgÃ¥ng}} or ''StÃ¥nggÃ¥ng'') was an invention of the [[mining industry]] that enabled the mechanical movement generated by a water wheel (German: ''Kunstrad'') to be transferred over short distances.<ref name="Quelle 1">''BergmÃ¤nnisches WÃ¶rterbuch.'' Bey Johann Christoph StÃ¶Ãel, Chemnitz 1778</ref> It was invented in the 16th century and by the 18th century was being used to transmit power up to four kilometres.<ref>''Stronger Than a Hundred Men: A History of the Vertical Water Wheel'' Terry S. Reynolds 1983</ref> Flatrod systems were widely used in the [[Harz]] and [[Ore Mountains]] of Germany as well as in [[Cornwall]], [[England]] and [[Bergslagen]] in [[Sweden]].
A replica of a flatrod system may be seen in [[Bad KÃ¶sen]] in Germany on the River [[Saale]]<ref>[http://blaues-band.de/saale/index.htm?badkoesen.htm Blaues Band durch Sachsen-Anhalt: Bad KÃ¶sen]</ref> and there is a replica water wheel, used to drive flatrods, in [[Clausthal-Zellerfeld]] in the [[Upper Harz]], formerly the biggest mining region in Europe.
== Fundamentals == [[File:SÃ¶rdalens konstgÃ¥ng 2012.webm|thumb|thumbtime=8|Function (video) of the flatrod system in SÃ¶rdalen, [[Sweden]].]] The flatrod system dates to the period before the invention of the [[steam engine]] and [[electricity]]. Using flatrods it was possible to operate [[man engine]]s and pumping systems, even though the water wheel in question had a rotary, not a reciprocal, motion. So that the rods could be made to move in a reciprocal fashion, a change of direction had to be achieved by means of specially shaped components.<ref name="Quelle 3">Franz Adolf FÃ¼rer: ''Salzbergbau und Salinenkunde.'' Druck und Verlag von Friedrich Vieweg und Sohn, Braunschweig 1900</ref> The components of the system that were mounted in the [[shaft mining|mining shaft]] were called shaft rods (''SchachtgestÃ¤nge'') or pump rods (''HubgestÃ¤nge''). Systems mounted in [[drift mines]] were called drift rods (''StreckengestÃ¤nge'').<ref>''Bericht vom Bergbau.'' Bey Siegfried Leberecht Crusius, Leipzig 1772</ref>
The flatrods (''FeldgestÃ¤nge'') themselves were used to transfer power over greater distances between the main engine and the pump rods.<ref name="Quelle 3" /> Iron collars (''Kunstringe'') were fitted onto the wheel axles, connecting pipes (''AnsetzrÃ¶hren'') and metal sleeves (''Ansteckkielen'') as well as certain parts of the wooden flatrods. The actual rods (''Kunststangen'') were long squared timbers that transmitted the power horizontally or at an incline. They had articulated iron joints (''KunstschlÃ¶sser'' or ''StangenschlÃ¶sser'') that were designed such that they could be interleaved into one another and secured with bolts or screws.<ref>Carl Friedrich Richter: ''Neuestes Berg-und HÃ¼tten-Lexikon.'' Erster Band, Kleefeldsche Buchhandlung, Leipzig 1805</ref>
== Lifting rods == [[File:Man engine animation.gif|thumb|Flatrod system in operation]] The lifting rod system ran vertically up the [[shaft mining|mineshaft]], either to transfer power to the individual sets of shaft pumps (when they were known as pump rods) or, in the case of man engines, to operate the man engine rods. In some cases the lifting rod system performed both duties. It consisted of roughly 19 to 20 centimetre thick squared spruce timbers. The poles were dovetailed at the ends and sides and were fixed to one another with correspondingly mortised wooden joints (''Holzlaschen''). These joints were tightly bound to the ends of the lifting rods with iron collars. In addition the iron collars were prevented from slipping by bolts inserted through them. At set distances there were also hooks on the sides that were used to hang the piston rods (''Kolbenstangen''). So that the horizontal movement of the flat rods could be turned into a vertical movement, a rotating cross-shaped lever (''Kunstkreuz'') was fitted to the lifting rods. Connexion to the cross lever was achieved using a crank (''Kunstschloss''). To balance the load it was usual to have two lifting rods.<ref name="Quelle 3" />
== Flatrods == [[File:Pershyttan konstgÃ¥ng 01.JPG|thumb|Horizontal flatrod system in Pershyttan near [[Nora (Sweden)]]]] [[File:Schacht am Carler Teich.jpg|thumb|Replica of the flatrod system at the Carler Teich, Clausthal-Zellerfeld]] The purpose of the flatrods was to transfer the power of the motive engine over greater distances to the pump rods in the shaft. This was necessary if the motive engine could not be mounted above or immediately next to the mine shaft. A flatrod system had the disadvantage that there were additional efficiency losses due to the greater masses that had to be moved. The reciprocal motion in the joints (''SchlÃ¶sser'') of the interconnected flatrods lead to lifting losses of from 25 to 50 percent.<ref name="Quelle 2">Joh. Jos. Prechtl (ed.): ''Technologische EncyklopÃ¤die oder alphabetisches Handbuch der Technologie, der technischen Chemie und des Maschinenwesens.'' FÃ¼nfter Band, Verlag der J. G. Gotta'schen Buchhandlung, Stuttgart, 1834</ref> In addition the construction of flatrods required additional timber. This was very maintenance-intensive due to the effects of weathering and it needed additional staff to inspect and maintain the flatrods.
The flatrods consisted of several wooden rods, fitted with iron hinges. At the ends of the rods, on either side, were so-called ''KunstschlÃ¶sser''. These were cut to fit in such a way that one rod could be mortised into another. This was necessary so that the flatrods could not slide apart as a result of to-and-fro or up-and-down motion.<ref name="Quelle 1" />
There were two types of flatrod: flatrods with rollers and flatrods with oscillating cranks (''Schwingen''). The former were laid on rollers. The rollers consisted of round timbers about eight to ten inches thick, that were firmly set into the ground on their underside and fixed in place with braces. In order to minimise friction, the rod was fitted with a drag rail (''Schleppschiene'') in the area of the individual rollers that was made of beechwood and long enough to for the entire stroke length.<ref name="Quelle 2" /> <!--
Das FeldgestÃ¤nge mit Schwingen besteht aus einer groÃen Schwinge, dem sogenannten Wagbaum, aus mehreren kleinen Schwingen, den Feldstangen, und den sogenannten LÃ¶cken mit StraÃbÃ¤umen. In der Mitte der Hauptschwinge befindet sich ein durchlaufender Zapfen, auf dem sie sich im Pfoteisen bewegt. An den beiden Enden der Hauptschwinge sind mehrere LÃ¶cher eingebracht, in denen mit eisernen Ringen befestigte Augeisen eingefÃ¼gt sind. In jedem Augeisen sind bis zu drei Augen, in die auf der einen Seite die Korbstange und auf der anderen Seite die Feldstange eingehÃ¤ngt werden. Um den Hub variabel zu machen, werden extra mehrere Augen angebracht. Um den Hub lÃ¤nger oder kÃ¼rzer zu machen, wird die Korbstange entsprechend eingehÃ¤ngt. Die Schwingarme der kleineren Schwingen dienen dazu, das FeldgestÃ¤nge entsprechend anzupassen. Diese Anpassung ist erforderlich, da das FeldgestÃ¤nge ansonsten aufgrund seiner LÃ¤nge leicht brechen wÃ¼rde. Die sogenannten LÃ¶cke sind erhÃ¶hte Unterlagen fÃ¼r die Schwingen. Sie werden alle 2 bis 3 [[Klafter]] aufgestellt und haben am oberen Ende krumme Stangen - die sogenannten Stecklinge. Die LÃ¶cke werden mit Spreizen und UnterlageklÃ¶tzen so versehen, dass das GestÃ¤nge hÃ¶henmÃ¤Ãig so angepasst wird, damit die Feldstangen sich in gerader Linie bewegen kÃ¶nnen. SÃ¤mtliche Zapfen an den Schwingen sind so angepasst, dass sie von beiden gleichweit entfernt sind.<ref>Carl Stegmayer: ''Handbuch der Bergbaukunst fÃ¼r Jedermann.'' Verlag von J. L. Kober, Prag 1862</ref>
== Bewegungsrichtungsumkehr == [[Bild:kunstgestaenge.png|miniatur|Prinzipskizze der Bewegungsrichtungsumkehr]] [[Bild:Kunstrad.jpg|miniatur|Rekonstruktion eines Kunstrades mit 11,5m Durchmesser, [[Clausthal-Zellerfeld]]]] Bei der Umkehrung der Bewegung von der Drehbewegung in die horizontale oder vertikale Bewegung, aber auch von der horizontale Bewegung in die vertikale Bewegung, bediente man sich speziell geformter GestÃ¤ngeteile: zum einen dem '''Krummzapfen''' und zum anderen dem '''Kunstkreuz'''.
Der Krummzapfen ist ein unter einem rechten Winkel gebogenes GestÃ¤ngeteil, das als Fortsetzung des Wellenzapfens dient. Seine Aufgabe ist es, die Drehbewegung des [[Wasserrad]]es in eine horizontale oder vertikale Bewegung umzuformen.<ref> Carl von Scheuchenstuel: ''IDIOTICON der Ã¶sterreichischen Berg- und HÃ¼ttensprache.'' k. k. HofbuchhÃ¤ndler Wilhelm BraumÃ¼ller, Wien 1856</ref> An dem Krummzapfen befand sich die sogenannte Korb- oder BlÃ¤uelstange. Mit dem ''krummen Zapfen'' wurde die Rotationsbewegung des Kunstrades auf das FeldgestÃ¤nge oder das SchachtgestÃ¤nge Ã¼bertragen, das daraufhin Pendelbewegungen ausfÃ¼hrt. Die Funktionsweise des Krummzapfens ist sehr Ã¤hnlich mit der Funktion einer heutigen [[Kurbelwelle]] und die BlÃ¤uelstange mit der Funktion eines [[Pleuel]]s zu vergleichen.
Das Kunstkreuz, auch ''Bruchzwinge'', ''Kunstwinkel'' oder einfach nur ''Kreuz'' genannt, besteht aus einem starken hÃ¶lzernen Winkelhebel. Das Kunstkreuz wurde entweder direkt an der Korbstange des Krummzapfens angeschlossen oder Ã¼ber ein FeldgestÃ¤nge damit verbunden. Es gab drei verschiedene Arten von Kunstkreuzen. Je nach Konstruktion bezeichnete man sie als ganze Kunstkreuze, halbe Kunstkreuze oder Viertelskreuze. Das ganze Kunstkreuz ist ein Kreuz mit vier Armen. Von diesen Armen werden jeweils zwei sich gegenÃ¼berstehende Arme an das SchachtgestÃ¤nge und die beiden anderen Arme an das FeldgestÃ¤nge angeschlossen. Das halbe Kreuz ist ein Kreuz mit drei Armen. Zwei Arme liegen dabei horizontal, der dritte steht aufrecht. An die beiden horizontalen Arme wurde das SchachtgestÃ¤nge und an den dritten Arm die Korbstange angeschlossen. Beim Viertelkreuz wird ein Arm an das GestÃ¤nge und ein Arm an die BlÃ¤uelstange angeschlossen.<ref>Heinrich Veith: ''Deutsches BergwÃ¶rterbuch mit Belegen.'' Verlag von Wilhelm Gottlieb Korn, Breslau 1871</ref>
Die Verwendung von Kunstkreuzen war zur Kraftumlenkung aus verschiedenen GrÃ¼nden unentbehrlich. Selbst wenn das Kunstrad direkt Ã¼ber dem Kunstschacht montiert war, entstand durch das direkte AnhÃ¤ngen der SchachtgestÃ¤nge an den Krummzapfen eine sehr hohe Belastung der sogenannten Kurbelwarzen. Auch war die [[Reibung]] bei der Direktmontage wesentlich grÃ¶Ãer. AuÃerdem erzeugten die Schachtstangen nie eine ganz "saubere" senkrechte Bewegung, sondern pendelten seitlich etwas hin und her.<ref>Johann Heinrich Moritz Poppe: ''EncyclopÃ¤die des gesammten Maschinenwesens, oder vollstÃ¤ndiger Unterricht in der praktischen Mechanik und Maschinenlehre.'' Dritter Theil, bey Georg VoÃ, Leipzig 1806</ref> -->

[[File:ILSC in progress.jpg|thumb|right|An ILSC scan in progress]]'''Intelligent laser speckle classification''', or '''ILSC''', is a scanning method used to discriminate between various micro-textural structures, such as the [[cellular component]]s in human skin.<ref name=Photonics>{{cite web|title=Noninvasive Imaging Method Promising for Skin Assessment|url=http://www.photonics.com/Article.aspx?AID=56111|publisher=Photonics|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> or discriminates sub-surface characteristics of any material (e.g. industrial, pharmaceutical, etc.)
==Basic concept== An ILSC scanner is composed mainly of two instruments: A [[laser]] and a modified [[Charge-coupled device#Color cameras|CCD camera]]. [[File:ILSC Diagram.png|thumb|right|Diagram of an ILSC scan]] Light from the laser interacts uniquely with various micro-textural structures, creating a specific laser speckle effect (or ''signature''). This signature can then be read by the incorporated camera, which utilizes [[Bayesian inference]] and inbuilt libraries of micro-textures to create a "laser speckle image" of the target.<ref name="K University">{{cite web|title=Laser Doppler, speckle and related techniques for blood perfusion mapping and imaging|url=http://home.lu.lv/~ozoma/Ma%ECistri-2013/Diagnostika_un_terapija/terap/Asins-pluusmas-meeriisanai-dazi-info/PM_R35.pdf|publisher=Kingston University|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> Since the method is comparative, it may also be used to differentiate very small changes in micro-structural objects, for example, a change in cell size. This ability to generate "comparative" laser speckle images is again due to the interactions between the laser and the cellular objects.<ref>Orun, A.B, E. Goodyer, H.Seker, G. Smith, V.Uslan And D. Chauhan, "Optimized parametric skin modelling for diagnosis of skin abnormalities by combining light back-scatter and laser speckle imaging", Skin Research and Technology, 2014; 1-13. doi:10.1111/srt.12142 </ref>
==Applications== The concept has been found to be very effective in analyzing human skin for issues caused by ageing, especially in the lower layers of the [[epidermis]], such as the [[Stratum basale|basal layer]], and has also been found to be less invasive than other methods, such as [[confocal microscopy]].<ref name="DM University">{{cite web|last1=Orun|first1=Ahmet|title=An improvement of skin aging assessment by non-invasive laser speckle effect: A comparative texture analysis|url=http://www.tech.dmu.ac.uk/~eg/ref/IEEE_BHI2014_Orun_Seker_203.pdf|publisher=De Montfort University|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> The potential application areas of ILSC are as follows :
'''- Skin analysis:''' it is possible to make an automated parametric discrimination between the two different conditions of skin (e.g. normal or effected by a disease)that are invisible to human eye. This would be particularly very useful for early diagnosis of the systemic diseases where the skin does not yet exhibits their visual effects by the surface changes [3]
'''- Pharmaceutical inspection :'''ILSC is also used for pharmaceitical product inspection as the laser light (with an ideal wavelength) can penetrate into the pharmaceutical (tablet) subsurface and scatters back by conveying the subsurface material characteristics to be identified and analysed by ILSC technique <ref>5. Orun, A. and G.Smith, "Micro-Structural Analysis of Tablet Surface Layers by Intelligent Laser Speckle Classification (ILSC) Technique: an Application in the Study of both Surface Defects and Subsurface Granule Structures",Journal of Pharmaceutical Innovation, (2017)DOI 10.1007/s12247-017-9290-0</ref> # '''- Industrial material identification :''' Depending on laser-material surface interaction, ILSC can identify and discriminate the different materials that are used in industrial production areas (e.g. metal, wood, plastic, etc.)<ref>6. Orun, A. and A. Alkis, "Material identification by surface reflection analysis in combination with bundle adjustment technique", Pattern Recognition Letters,24(2003)</ref> to make the production process in fully automated form by eliminating the most of environmental undesired lightening effects.

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}}
'''Lilug''' or '''Long Island Linux User Group, Inc.''', is a [[Linux user group]] based in [[New York State]].
Lilug is an official [[not-for-profit organization]], incorporated under Section 402 of the New York State Not-For-Profit [[corporation law]]. It is dedicated to spreading public awareness about [[Linux]], and helping others to become more familiar with it.
The group was formed in December 1998, out of interested parties from two previously-existing organizations, the [[Farmingdale, New York|Farmingdale]] Linux and Associated Technologies Club and the [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]] Local Linux Users Group. It meets monthly on the second Tuesday of each month on the [[Cold Spring Harbor, New York|Cold Spring Harbor]] Lab Woodbury Campus, in the Woodbury Auditorium.<ref>http://lilug.org/wiki/GeneralMeetingDirections</ref>
== Special Interest Groups == Lilug has two special interest groups, one for developers and one for security.<ref>http://lilug.org/wiki/Lilug</ref> The SIGs are usually smaller events with a more discussion-oriented approach.
== Notable speakers == * [[Eric S. Raymond]]<ref>http://www.osnews.com/story/21192</ref> * Mushon Zer-Aviv of the [[ShiftSpace]] project * Matt Norwood of the [[SFLC]] * Mark Jason Dominus
== See also == * [[Linux user group]] * [[Free software movement]]
==External links== * [http://lilug.org/ The official Lilug website] * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=LILUG Video Archive of talks presented at LILUG]

{{good article}} [[File:IAI_Harop_PAS_2013_01.jpg|thumb|right|[[IAI Harop]] a loitering munition optimized for the [[Suppression of Enemy Air Defenses]] (SEAD) role, the initial use of loitering munitions]]
A '''loitering munition''' (also known as a '''suicide drone'''<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/US-army-may-use-soon-Israeli-designed-suicide-drones-455572 US army may soon use Israeli-designed âsuicide dronesâ], ''Jerusalem Post'', June 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.israeldefense.co.il/en/node/28716 China Unveils a Harpy-Type Loitering Munition], Israel Defense, March 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/4760/meet-israels-suicide-squad-of-self-sacrificing-drones Meet Israelâs âSuicide Squadâ of Self-Sacrificing Drones], The Drive, August 2016</ref><ref name="auto3"/> or '''kamikaze drone'''<ref>[https://www.cnet.com/news/kamikaze-drone-loiters-above-waits-for-target/ Kamikaze drone loiters above, waits for target], CNET, June 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.c4isrnet.com/story/military-tech/omr/missile-defense/2015/08/13/kamikaze-drones-add-new-layer-lethality-remote-forces/31405521/ 'Kamikaze drones' add a new layer of lethality to remote force], C4ISRNET, August 2015</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/04/05/israeli-made-kamikaze-drone-spotted-in-nagorno-karabakh-conflict/ Israeli-made kamikaze drone spotted in Nagorno-Karabakh conflict], ''Washington Post'', April 2016</ref>) is a weapon system category in which the [[munition]] [[Loiter (aeronautics)|loiters]] around the target area for some time, searches for targets, and attacks once a target is located.<ref>[http://aviationweek.com/defense/loitering-munition-availability-expanding-internationally Loitering Munition Availability Expanding Internationally], ''Aviation Week'', April 2016</ref><ref>[http://i-hls.com/archives/73521 Loitering Weapon Systems â A Growing Demand], h-ils, December 2016</ref><ref name="auto">[http://www.popsci.com/watch-drone-turn-missile Watch This Drone Turn Into A Missile], ''Popular Science'', August 2015</ref> Loitering munitions enable faster reaction times against concealed or hidden targets that emerge for short periods without placing high-value [[weapons platform|platforms]] close to the target area, and also allow more selective targeting as the actual attack mission can be aborted.
Loitering munitions fit in the niche between [[cruise missile]]s and [[unmanned combat aerial vehicle]]s (UCAVs) sharing characteristics with both. They differ from cruise missiles in that they are designed to loiter for a relatively long time around the target area, and from UCAVs in that a loitering munition is intended to be expended in an attack and has a built-in warhead.
Loitering weapons first emerged in the 1980s for use in the [[Suppression of Enemy Air Defenses]] (SEAD) role against [[surface-to-air missile]]s (SAMs), and were deployed for the SEAD role in a number of military forces in the 1990s. Starting in the 2000s, loitering weapons have been developed for additional roles ranging from relatively long-range strikes and fire support down to tactical, very short range battlefield systems that fit in a backpack.
Loitering munitions have proliferated into use by at least 14 countries, with several different types in use as of 2017. The rising proliferation and the ability to use some systems as [[lethal autonomous weapon]]s coupled with ethical concerns over such use have led to research and discussion by [[International humanitarian law]] scholars and activists.
==History== === First development and terminology === [[File:Northrop AGM-136A Tacit Rainbow.jpg|thumb|[[Northrop Corporation|Northrop]] [[AGM-136 Tacit Rainbow]] on display at the National Museum of the U.S. Air Force in Dayton, Ohio.]]
Initially, loitering munitions were not referred to as such but rather as suicide UAVs or loitering missiles. Different sources point at different projects as originating the weapon category. The early 1980s initial Israeli [[Delilah (missile)|Delilah]] variants<ref name="www.iaf.org.il IAF"/><ref>[http://defense-update.com/20090614_loitering_weapons.html Loitering Weapons are making a Comeback], Defense Update, June 2009</ref> or the failed US [[AGM-136 Tacit Rainbow]] program<ref>[https://www.files.ethz.ch/isn/188865/Ethical%20Autonomy%20Working%20Paper_021015_v02.pdf An Introduction to Autonomy in Weapon Systems], pages 13-14, By: Paul Scharre and Michael C. Horowitz, CNAS Working paper, Feb 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/1988/October%201988/1088uav.pdf Canan, James W. "Unmanned Aerial Vehicles." Air Force Magazine (1988).], page 87</ref> are mentioned by some sources. Alternatively, the late 1980s [[IAI Harpy]] which was widely exported is considered by some as the first loitering munition system.<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=DB7xDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA106&dq=Harpy+UAV&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Harpy%20UAV&f=false Drone Strike!: UCAVs and Aerial Warfare in the 21st Century]'', By Bill Yenne, {{ISBN|9781580072526}}, pages 106-107</ref>
[[File:Paris Air Show 2007-06-24 n25.jpg|thumb|[[IAI Harpy]] first-generation loitering munition for SEAD role]]
Early projects did not use the "loitering munition" nomenclature which emerged at a much later date, and used existing terminology at the time. For instance the AGM-136 Tacit Rainbow was described as follows in a 1988 ''[[Air Force Magazine]]'' article: {{Quote|text=the Tacit Rainbow unmanned jet aircraft being developed by Northrop to loiter on high and then swoop down on enemy radars could be called a UAV, a cruise missile, or even a standoff weapon. But it is most definitely not an RPV.|source=[http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/1988/October%201988/1088uav.pdf Canan, James W. "Unmanned Aerial Vehicles." ''Air Force Magazine'' (1988)], page 87}}
=== Initial role in suppression of enemy air defense=== [[File:Syrian SAM.jpg|thumb|Part of a Syrian [[SA-6]] overlooking the Beqaa Valley, in early 1982]] The response to the first generation of fixed installation [[surface-to-air missile]]s (SAMs) such as [[SA-2]] and [[SA-3]] was the development of the [[anti-radiation missile]] such as [[AGM-45 Shrike]] and other means to attack fixed SAM installations, as well as developing SEAD doctrines. The [[Soviet]] counter-response was the use of mobile SAMs such as [[SA-6]] with intermittent use of [[radar]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Principles of Modern Radar|first=Edward K.|last=Reedy|editor-first1=Jerry L.|editor-last1=Eaves|editor-first2=Edward K.|editor-last2=Reedy|date=1 January 1987|publisher=Springer US|pages=681â699|doi=10.1007/978-1-4613-1971-9_22|chapter = Radar ECCM Considerations and Techniques|isbn = 978-1-4612-9170-1}}</ref> Thus, the SAM battery was only visible for a small period of time, during which it was also a significant threat to high-value [[Wild Weasel]] fighters. In 1982 [[Operation Mole Cricket 19]] various means including [[UAV]]s and air-launched [[ADM-141 TALD|Samson decoys]] were used over suspected SAM areas to saturate enemy SAMs and to bait them to activate their radar systems, which were then attacked by anti-radiation missiles.<ref>[http://www.iaf.org.il/625-19927-he/IAF.aspx Six Days in June (Hebrew)], IAF bulletin, issue 145, June 2002</ref><ref>[http://www.ausairpower.net/APA-SAM-Effectiveness.html Surface to Air Missile Effectiveness in Past Conflicts], Technical Report APA-TR-2010-1001, Dr Carlo Kopp, AFAIAA, SMIEEE, PEng, October 2010</ref>
In the 1980s, a number of programs, such as the IAI Harpy or the AGM-136 Tacit Rainbow, integrated anti-radiation sensors into a drone or missile air frames coupled with command and control and loitering capabilities. This allowed the attacking force to place relatively cheap munitions in place over suspected SAM sites, and to attack promptly the moment the SAM battery is visible. This integrated the use of a drone as a baiting decoy with the attack role into one small and relatively cheap platform in comparison to the alternative wild weasel jet fighter.<ref>[http://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/4760/meet-israels-suicide-squad-of-self-sacrificing-drones Meet Israel's 'Suicide Squad' of Self-Sacrificing Drones], August 2016, The Drive</ref><ref>[http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a552529.pdf ADAPTIVE DISCRETE EVENT SIMULATION FOR ANALYSIS OF HARPY SWARM ATTACK], Brandon J. Cobb, Naval Postgraduate School, Thesis, September 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA420687|title=Suminsby, Robert E. Fear no Evil: Unmanned combat air vehicles for suppression of enemy air defenses. AIR UNIV MAXWELL AFB AL AEROSPACE STUDIES INST, 2002.|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2001/June/Pages/Loitering7024.aspx Loitering, Smart Cruise Missile Marketed to U.S. Navy], National Defense, June 2001</ref>
===Evolution into additional roles=== [[Image:NLOS-LS missile test launch from truck.jpg|thumb|[[XM501 Non-Line-of-Sight Launch System|XM501]] US prototype capable of launching LAM (loitering attack munition)]]
Starting in the 2000s, loitering weapons have been developed for additional roles beyond the initial SEAD role ranging from relatively long-range strikes and fire support<ref>[http://defense-update.com/20110914_fire-shadow-afghanistan.html British Army Sets to Deploy Fire Shadow Loitering Weapons to Afghanistan by Early 2012] Defense Update, September 2011</ref> down to tactical, very short-range battlefield use such as the [[AeroVironment Switchblade]] which is deployed at the [[platoon]] level and fits in a backpack.<ref>[http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2011/July/Pages/MilitaryInvestigatesKillerDronesThatCanFitinRucksacks.aspx Military Investigates Killer Drones That Can Fit in Rucksacks] National Defense, July 2011</ref><ref>[https://medium.com/war-is-boring/a-tiny-missile-that-waits-overhead-silent-patient-and-deadly-6f5a0093cab0 A Tiny Missile That Waits OverheadâSilent, Patient and Deadly, WarIsBoring], January 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.upi.com/Defense-News/2016/10/03/AeroVironment-producing-Switchblade-missiles-for-Army/1391475510902/ AeroVironment producing Switchblade missiles for Army] UPI, October 2016</ref><ref>[http://defense-update.com/features/du-1-07/armedUAVs_8.htm Loitering Autonomous Weapons], Defense Update, January 2007</ref> A documented use of loitering munitions was in [[2016 Nagorno-Karabakh clashes]] in which an [[IAI Harop]] was used against a bus functioning as a troop transport.<ref name="auto2">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/04/05/israeli-made-kamikaze-drone-spotted-in-nagorno-karabakh-conflict/ Israeli-made kamikaze drone spotted in Nagorno-Karabakh conflict], ''Washington Post'', April 2016</ref>
==Characteristics== [[File:Delilah missile side.jpg|thumb|Air-launched Delilah loitering munition, controlled by backseat [[Weapon systems officer|WSO]]]]
Loitering munitions may be as simple as an [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] (UAV) with attached explosives that is sent on a potential ''kamikaze'' mission, and may even be constructed with off the shelf commercial [[quadcopter]]s with strapped on explosives.<ref name="auto1">[http://www.popularmechanics.com/military/weapons/a23350/isis-using-kamikaze-drones-in-iraq/ ISIS Using Kamikaze Drones in Iraq], ''Popular Mechanics'', October 2016</ref>
Purpose built munitions are more elaborate in flight and control capabilities, warhead size and design, and on-board sensors for locating targets.<ref name="iClean">[http://www.dror-aero.com/ac/iclean/iclean_fr.pdf iClean â Loitering Attack UCAV], Artzi Dror, Technion Institute of Technology, 2012</ref> Some loitering munitions use a human operator to locate targets whereas others, such as IAI Harop, can function autonomously searching and launching attacks without human intervention.<ref>[http://defense-update.com/products/h/harop.html Israel Unveils Loitering Anti-Missile Drone], Defense Update, 2009</ref><ref>[http://defense-update.com/directory/harpy.htm Harpy Air Defense Suppression System], Defense Update, 2006</ref>
Some loitering munitions may return and be recovered by the operator if they are unused in an attack and have enough fuel; in particular this is characteristic of [[UAV]]s with a secondary suicide mission.<ref>[http://defense-update.com/20160216_rotem.html IAI's ROTEM â Tactical Multirotor Killer Drone], Defense Update, 2016</ref> Other systems, such as [[Delilah (missile)|Delilah]]<ref name="www.iaf.org.il IAF">[http://www.iaf.org.il/2158-28495-he/IAF.aspx The Secrets of Delialah (Hebrew)], IAF bulletin, issue 184, December 2008</ref><ref>[http://defense-update.com/20090614_delilah-loitering-missile.html Delilah â The IAF Loitering Missile], Defense Update, June 2009</ref> or IAI Harop,<ref name="auto"/> don't have a recovery option and are self-destructed in mission aborts.
==Comparison to similar weapons== Loitering munitions fit in the niche between cruise missiles and unmanned combat aerial vehicles (UCAVs).<ref name="auto"/><ref name=Gilli1>[https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09636412.2016.1134189 Gilli, Andrea, and Mauro Gilli. "The Diffusion of Drone Warfare? Industrial, Organizational and Infrastructural Constraints: Military Innovations and the Ecosystem Challenge." (2015).], pages 21â22, 25â31</ref>
The following table compares similar size-class cruise missiles, loitering munitions, and UCAVS: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Characteristic !! Cruise missile !! Loitering munition !! UCAV |- | Cost appropriate for expendable one-time use || Yes || Yes || No, but high cost allows for higher-quality platform |- | Recovery possible after launch || No || Usually no || Yes, typical mission profile is round-trip |- | Built-in warhead || Yes || Yes || No |- | Stealthy final dive to target || Usually yes || Usually yes || Usually no |- | Loitering || No or limited || Yes || Usually yes |- | Sensors for target acquisition || Limited || Yes || Usually yes |- | command and control during flight || Usually limited || Yes || Yes |- | Range || Longer, optimized for constant speed flight || Shorter || Shorter, even shorter for typical round-trip mission |- | Speed || Typically higher || Typically lower || Depends on role |- | Example type|| [[File:Tomahawk Block IV cruise missile.jpg|thumb|Block IV [[Tomahawk cruise missile]]. Small wing area is optimized for high-speed cruise.]] || [[File:IAI_Harop_PAS_2013_01.jpg|thumb|[[IAI Harop]] a loitering munition optimized for the [[Suppression of Enemy Air Defenses]] (SEAD) role]] || [[File:MQ-1_Predator_unmanned_aircraft.jpg|thumb|[[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator]] [[UCAV]]]] |- | Range || 1,600 km || 1,000 km || 1,100 km |- | Max speed || high sub-sonic, 880 km/h || 190 km/h || 217 km/h |- | Flight endurance || c. 2 hours || 6 hours || 24 hours |- | Engine || 3.1 kilonewtons (700 lbf) F107-WR-402 turbofan engine || 37 hp Wankel engine || 115 hp Rotax 914F |- | Loaded system weight || 1,588 kg || 135 kg || 1,020 kg |- | Payload || 450 kg warhead|| 23 kg warhead|| 2 Ã [[AGM-114 Hellfire]] or 6 Ã [[AGM-176 Griffin]] air-to-surface missiles |- | Length || 6.25 m || 2.5 m || 8.22 m |- | Wingspan || 2.67 m <ref>[http://www.fi-aeroweb.com/Defense/Tomahawk.html RGM/UGM-109 Tomahawk], fi-aeroweb, November 2014</ref>|| 3.0 m <ref name="iClean"/>|| 16.8 m <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20111216191110/http://www.af.mil/information/factsheets/factsheet.asp?fsID=122 MQ-1B Predator factsheet], US Air Force, July 2010</ref> |} Whereas some cruise missiles, such as [[Tomahawk (missile)|the block IV Tomahawk]], have the ability to loiter and have some sensory and remote control features,<ref>[http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/the-us-navy-has-big-plans-the-lethal-tomahawk-missile-16261?page=2 The U.S. Navy Has Big Plans for the Lethal Tomahawk Missile], The National Interest, Kris Osborn, 18th May 2016</ref> their primary mission is typically strike and not target acquisition. Cruise missiles, as their name implies, are optimized for long-range flight at constant speed both in terms of propulsion systems and [[wings]] or [[lifting body]] design. They are often unable to loiter at slow fuel-efficient speeds which significantly reduces potential loiter time even when the missile has some loiter capabilities.<ref>Takahashi, Timothy, et al. "A multi-disciplinary survey of advanced subsonic tactical cruise missile configurations." 43rd AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit. 2005.</ref>
Conversely almost any [[UAV]] could be piloted to crash onto a target in a suicide attack and most could be fitted with an improvised explosive warhead.<ref name="auto1"/> However the primary use of a [[UAV]] or [[UCAV]] would be for recoverable flight operations carrying reconnaissance equipment and/or munitions. While many UAV designs are explicitly designed with loitering in mind, they are not optimized for a diving attack often lacking forward facing cameras, lacking in control response-speed which is unneeded in regular UAV flight, and are noisy when diving at the target potentially providing warning to the target. UAV's, being designed as multi-use platforms, often have a unit cost that is not appropriate for regular one-time expendable mission use.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rusi.org/sites/default/files/200808_op_unmanned_combat_air_vehicles.pdf|title=Franklin, Michael. "Unmanned combat air vehicles: opportunities for the guided weapons industry?." RUSI Occasional Paper, www. rusi. org/downloads/assets/Unmanned_Combat_Air_Vehicles. pdf (29.3. 2011) (2008).|author=|date=|website=RUSI.org|access-date=15 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=Gilli1/>
The primary mission of a loitering munition is reaching the suspected target area, target acquisition during a loitering phase, followed by a suicide strike, and the munition is optimized in this regard in terms of characteristics (e.g. very short engine life time, silence in strike phase, speed of strike dive, optimization toward loitering time instead of range/speed) and unit cost (appropriate for a one-off strike mission).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantis-press.com/php/download_paper.php?id=25855976|title=Liu, Xuancen, et al. "Optimal Design of Loitering Munition Trajectory in Complex Battlefield Environment." (2016).|publisher=Atlantis Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oai.dtic.mil/oai/oai?verb=getRecord&metadataPrefix=html&identifier=ADA551913|title=Design Requirements for Weaponizing Man-Portable UAS in Support of Counter-Sniper Operations|first=Derek J.|last=Snyder|date=25 April 2017|publisher=|via=Defense Technical Information Center}}</ref>
==Ethical and international humanitarian law concerns== {{Main article|Lethal autonomous weapon#Ethical and legal issues}}
Loitering munitions that are capable of making autonomous attack decisions (man out of the loop) raise moral, ethical, and international humanitarian law concerns because a human being is not involved in making the actual decision to attack and potentially kill humans. Whereas some guided munitions may [[lock-on after launch]] or may be sensor fuzed, their flight time is typically limited and a human launches them at an area where enemy activity is strongly suspected. An autonomous loitering munition, on the other hand, may be launched at an area where enemy activity is only probable, and loiter searching autonomously for targets for potentially hours following the initial launch decision. The IAI Harpy and IAI Harop are frequently cited in the relevant literature as they set a precedent for an aerial system (though not necessarily a precedent when comparing to a modern [[naval mine]]) in terms of length and quality of autonomous function, in relation to a cruise missile for example.<ref>Garcia, Denise. "Killer robots: Why the US should lead the ban." Global Policy 6.1 (2015): 57â63.</ref><ref>Sharkey, Noel. "Saying 'no!' to lethal autonomous targeting." Journal of Military Ethics 9.4 (2010): 369â383.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://munin.uit.no/bitstream/handle/10037/9931/thesis.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y|title=Mortensen, Erika Steinholt. Autonomous weapon systems that decide whom to kill. How international humanitarian law and international human rights law regulate the development and use of offensive autonomous weapon systems during international armed conflicts. MS thesis. UiT Norges arktiske universitet, 2016.|publisher=}}</ref><ref>Alston, Philip. "Lethal robotic technologies: the implications for human rights and international humanitarian law." JL Inf. & Sci. 21 (2011): 35.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/download/38978331/Autonomous-Systems-Publication_Print.pdf#page=120|title=Crootof, Rebecca. "The Varied Law of Autonomous Weapon Systems." (2015).|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evan Wallach and Erik Thomas|date=2016|title=The Economic Calculus of Fielding Autonomous Fighting Vehicles Compliant with the Laws of Armed Conflict|journal=Yale Journal of Law & Technology|volume=18|pages=1â25|url=http://yjolt.org/sites/default/files/Wallach_18YJoLT1.pdf}}</ref>
== Users and producers == As of 2017, loitering munitions are in use in several countries, including: *{{flag|Israel}} - [[IAI Harpy]], [[IAI Harop]], [[IAI Green Dragon]], [[IAI Rotem L]], [[Aeronautics Defense Orbiter]], [[Delilah (missile)|Delilah]], SkyStriker.<ref>[http://www.janes.com/article/63526/elbit-announces-new-skystriker-loitering-munition Elbit announces new SkyStriker loitering munition] Yaakov Lappin, Tel Aviv - IHS Jane's Defence Weekly 08 September 2016</ref> Indigenous manufacture of additional types by [[Israel Aerospace Industries]],<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/singapore-iai-reveals-new-family-of-loitering-munit-421989/ SINGAPORE: IAI reveals new family of loitering munitions], FlightGlobal, February 2016</ref> [[UVision]],<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/uvision-loitering-munitions-to-undergo-anti-tank-tes-424672/ UVision loitering munitions to undergo anti-tank testing], Flight Global, April 2016</ref><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/israeli-companies-pitching-loitering-munitions-for-u-423808/ Israeli companies pitching loitering munitions for US Army programme], FlightGlobal, April 2016</ref> [[Aeronautics Defense]],<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/aeronautics-introduces-orbiter-1k-loitering-munition-412651/ Aeronautics introduces Orbiter 1K loitering munition], FlightGlobal, May 2015</ref> [[Elbit Systems]],<ref>[http://www.janes.com/article/63526/elbit-announces-new-skystriker-loitering-munition Elbit announces new SkyStriker loitering munition], Jane's Defence Weekly, September 2016</ref> and [[Israel Military Industries]]<ref>[http://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/8219/vietnam-eyes-israels-delilah-standoff-missile-and-f-16s-could-be-next Vietnam Eyes Israel's Delilah Standoff Missile, and F-16s Could Be Next], The Warzone, March 2017</ref> *{{flag|United States}} - [[AeroVironment Switchblade]], [[Raytheon Coyote]]<ref>[http://www.janes.com/article/66954/surface-navy-2017-coyote-earmarked-for-isr-and-offensive-roles Surface Navy 2017: Coyote earmarked for ISR and offensive roles], Janes, January 2017</ref> *{{flag|China}} - IAI Harpy, [[CH-901]], [[WS-43]], [[ASN-301]]<ref>[http://www.janes.com/article/59623/dsa-2016-china-details-ch-901-uav-and-loitering-munition DSA 2016: China details CH-901 UAV and loitering munition], Janes, April 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.janes.com/article/68341/idex-2017-catic-reveals-details-about-harpy-type-loitering-munition IDEX 2017: CATIC reveals details about Harpy-type loitering munition], Janes, March 2017</ref> *{{flag|South Korea}} - [[File:FSImgs.jpg|thumb|right|250 px|Mud Gas Separator capable of handling 1000-1500gpm]][[File:FSImgsprocessflow.jpg|thumb|right|250 px| Process Flow Diagram For Mud Gas Separator]]
'''Mud Gas Separator''' is commonly called a '''gas-buster''' or '''poor boy [[degasser]]'''. It captures and separates the large volumes of free gas within the [[drilling fluid]]. If there is a "kick" situation, this vessel separates the mud and the gas by allowing it to flow over baffle plates. The gas then is forced to flow through a line, venting to a [[Gas flare|flare]]. A "kick" situation happens when the [[Annulus (oil well)|annular]] [[Fluid statics|hydrostatic pressure]] in a drilling well temporarily (and usually relatively suddenly) falls below that of the formation, or [[Pore water pressure|pore]], pressure in a [[Permeability (earth sciences)|permeable]] section [[Downhole oil water separation technology|downhole]], and before control of the situation is lost.
It is always safe to design the mud/gas separator that will handle the maximum possible gas flow that can occur.<ref>Dilling Fluids Processing Handbook {{ISBN|0-7506-7775-9}}</ref><ref>Mud Equipment Manual {{ISBN|0-87201-614-5}}</ref>
==Types of Mud/Gas Separators== The principle of mud/gas separation for different types of vessels is the same.<ref>SPE Drilling Engineering, December 1991</ref> * Closed bottom type * Open bottom type * Float type The closed-bottom separator, as the name implies, is closed at the vessel bottom with the mud return line directed back to the mud tanks. Commonly called the poor boy, the open-bottom [[mud gas separator]] is typically mounted on a mud tank or trip tank with the bottom of the separator body submerged in the mud. Fluid level (mud leg) is maintained in a float-type mud gas separator by a float/valve configuration. The float opens and closes a valve on the mud return line to maintain the mud-leg level.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aipusolidcontrol.com/html/products/gas-separator.html|title=Solids control Mud Gas Separators|}}</ref> According to pedestal or base type there are: * Fixed type * Elevating type
Poor boy degassers are usually named according to the vessel diameter. Types include: * MGS800 * MGS1000 * MGS1200 * MGS1400
The degasser type or configuration is typically customisable.
==Principle of operation== The principle behind the '''mud gas separator''' is relatively simple. On the figure, the mud and gas mixture is fed at the inlet allowing it to impinge on a series of baffles designed to separate gas and mud. The free gas then is moved into the flare line to reduce the threat of toxic and hazardous gases and the mud then discharges to the [[shale shaker]] and to the tank.

[[Image:MLCShape.svg|thumb|''MLC shape of an X-MLCs'']] A '''multileaf collimator''' ('''MLC''') is a device made up of individual "leaves" of a high atomic numbered material, usually [[tungsten]], that can move independently in and out of the path of a [[particle beam]] in order to block it.
MLCs are used on [[linear accelerator]]s to provide conformal shaping of [[radiotherapy]] treatment beams. Specifically, conformal radiotherapy and [[Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy]] (IMRT) can be delivered using MLCs.
The MLC has improved rapidly since its inception and the first use of leaves to shape structures in 1965 <ref>Takahashi, S., "Conformation radiotherapy: rotation techniques as applied to radiography and radiotherapy of cancer", ''Acta Radiol. Suppl. 242 (1965) 1â142''</ref> to modern day operation and use. MLCs are now widely used and have become an integral part of any radiotherapy department. MLCs were primarily used for conformal radiotherapy, and have allowed the cost effective implementation of conformal treatment with significant time saving,<ref>Brewster, L.; Mohan, R.; Mageras, G.; Burman, C.; Leibel, S. and Fuks, Z., "Three dimensional conformal treatment planning with multileaf collimators", ''Int. J. Rad. Onc. Biol. Phys. 33 (1995) 1081â9''</ref><ref>Helyer, S. J. and Heisig, S., "Multileaf collimation versus conventional shielding blocks: a time and motion study of beam shaping in radiotherapy", ''Rad. Onc. 37 (1995) 61â4''</ref> and also have been adapted for use for IMRT treatments. For conformal radiotherapy the MLC allows conformal shaping of the linear accelerator (LINAC) beam to match the borders of the target tumour. For intensity modulated treatments the leaves of a MLC can be moved across the field to create IMRT distributions (MLCs really provide a [[fluence]] modulation rather than intensity modulation).
The MLC is an important tool for radiation therapy dose delivery. It was originally used as a surrogate for alloy block field shaping and is now widely used for IMRT. As with any tool used in radiotherapy the MLC must undergo commissioning and quality assurance. Additional commissioning measurements are completed to model a MLC for treatment planning. Various MLCs are provided by different vendors and they all have unique design features as determined by specifications of design,<ref>Galvin, J. M.; Smith, A. R. and Lally, B., "Characterization of a multi-leaf collimator system", ''Int. J. Rad. Onc. Biol. Phys. 25 (1993) 181â92''</ref> and these differences are quite significant.
